awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Coping with Stress: Integrating Hormones, Behavior, Gene Expression, and Fitness
awd_abstract_narration:
The question of why some individuals are better at coping with stress than others is fundamental and pressing. Identifying the causes of differences in the stress response requires understanding how the stress response varies within and across populations, and how these differences affect survival and reproduction. Organisms respond to a diversity of stressors through behavior and physiology, and this response is important for coping with immediate threats, yet it can also impose substantial damage. Stress resilience is the rapid and effective termination of the stress response and may be an important predictor of the capacity to persist in changing environments. This research will address how stress responsiveness and stress resilience affects fitness across a range of environments. The results of these experiments could significantly advance understanding of the traits that drive vulnerability to stressors and adverse health outcomes, and help to predict the potential for individuals, populations, and species to persist in a changing environment. This research will be integrated with education and outreach in several ways. A partnership with the Cornell Lab of Ornithology's education program will produce accessible and engaging multimedia pieces on how organisms, including modern humans, cope with stress. These materials will be designed to enhance public interest in science, and to provide a standards-based resource for use in secondary schools and undergraduate biology courses nationwide. The research team is also collaborating with local environmental groups and researchers at each study site to develop field-based public outreach programs.

The researchers engaged in this collaborative project will experimentally manipulate phenotype and exposure to stressors in a widely distributed songbird, the tree swallow (Tachycineta bicolor), to determine whether variation in specific components of the stress response are causally linked to behavior, phenotypic damage, gene expression, and fitness. Novel techniques that enable the manipulation of the hormonal stress response in free-living and freely-behaving birds will be coupled with advances in remote monitoring and tracking to reveal the detailed behavioral changes and fitness effects of variation in the hormonal stress response. The potential for selection to shape the efficacy of negative feedback will be assessed by estimating the heritability and consistency of trait expression within and across seasons. Coordinated experiments across four populations that breed in differing environments from Alaska to Tennessee will address how variation in specific components of the stress response influence the ability to survive and reproduce in the presence of stressors. The data obtained through this project will be stored in databases maintained by the Principal Investigator and collaborators, and archived through the Cornell eCommons facility. Data will be provided as supplementary material to publications, and made publicly available within five years of the conclusion of the project.

por.por_cntn:
We live in a time of unprecedented global change. As climates shift, species distributions change, and anthropogenic effects become increasingly far-reaching. In consequence, populations are exposed to novel and more frequent stressors. For some individuals, and for some populations, this changing regime of stressors will present too great a challenge to survival and reproduction. Yet others will persist, coping and sometimes thriving despite the challenges. How do some individuals survive and reproduce despite the presence of stressors that prove fatal to others? To answer this question we need to examine the mechanisms that mediate the phenotypic stress response.

Organisms respond to a diversity of stressors by mounting coordinated changes in behavior and physiology. This response, which is hormonally mediated, is crucial to surviving a variety of challenges. Yet the same process that is invaluable in coping with immediate threats can also impose substantial damage over time. In addition to the pathological effects of long-term exposure to stress hormones, even relatively brief elevations can impair the expression of a variety of behaviors and physiological processes central to fitness, including reproduction and immune function.

A long-standing hypothesis in the field of stress physiology is that peak stress-induced glucocorticoid levels after exposure to a stressor influence the amount of phenotypic damage that the stress response imposes; however, experimental support for this hypothesis has been mixed. This project tested an alternative hypothesis, that the ability to rapidly and effectively terminate the stress response (through a process called negative feedback) influences the susceptibility to repeated or chronic stressors. Coordinated manipulations of phenotype and exposure to simulated stressors were conducted across four populations of a widely distributed songbird, the tree swallow (Tachycineta bicolor), ranging from Alaska to Wyoming to Tennessee. Additional experiments in our long-term study population (in New York) used a novel technique to non-invasively elevate circulating corticosterone levels in free-living birds to test its causal effects. Together, these experiments tested whether variation in the efficacy of negative feedback affects behavior, physiological state, gene expression, and fitness.

Our results supported the prediction that negative feedback is an important predictor of stress coping capacity. Individuals with naturally stronger negative feedback are better able to cope with experimental challenges, and also differ in their patterns of gene expression. However, this research also revealed that interactions between peak glucocorticoid levels and negative feedback often better predict stress coping capacity than either trait measured alone. Individuals that mount both a strong glucocorticoid stress response and have strong negative feedback are more stress resilient. This pattern was reflected in a comparative analysis, which found that birds from populations that breed in more unpredictable environments mount stronger acute stress responses and have stronger negative feedback. This suggests that selection may favor the ability to rapidly terminate the stress response in unpredictably challenging environments. Overall, these findings indicate that interactions among different components of glucocorticoid regulation are an important but overlooked influence on the capacity to cope with challenges.

Additional outcomes of this award include the development of frameworks of stress responsiveness, including a conceptual model of endocrine flexibility, and a system-based model of stress, and new insights into the role of context in influencing hormone-fitness relationships across taxa. This project also revealed that short-term increases in glucocorticoid hormones can have lingering effects on behavior, and identified several additional predictors of stress resilience, including genome-wide patterns of DNA methylation.

This project supported the mentoring and training of many young researchers, including undergraduate students (56 in total), graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers. It also supported scientific outreach in local communities near our study sites in Alaska, Tennessee, and New York through bird banding demonstrations, public talks, and educational events for K-12 students inside and outside the classroom. Another key outcome of the project was the production of an animated video ?What can we learn about stress from birds?? released on the Cornell Lab of Ornithology?s All About Birds website and their YouTube channel. This video, which is designed to teach core concepts in science, explains why humans and other animals respond to stress in the ways that we do, how hormones mediate the stress response, and how research in birds is helping to reveal how stress responses evolve.
